awd_titl_txt: Connecting Dynamics and Thermodynamics to Predict Mobility and Glassiness
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical abstract

This research will lead to new understanding of how certain very widely-used materials behave and why they sometimes misbehave. Some solid materials are crystalline; table salt and sugar are two familiar examples. In these cases the atoms or molecules that make up the solid are regularly positioned and highly organized, and their structure and properties do not change with time - they are at equilibrium.  In many other cases the solids are glassy, as if the particles in the liquid state were stuck in place. Window glass is just one example; it is made of small molecules containing silicon and oxygen.  A large fraction of specially designed materials, which often involve very large molecules known as polymers, are also in the glassy solid state.  Although glassy solids have been part of our surroundings for centuries, there are still aspects of their behavior that are not well understood. Examples from daily life include protective coatings, photoresists, polymers reinforced with nanoparticles, membranes, and filters. In each of these cases a significant fraction of the glassy solid molecules are near an interface; different kinds of experiments have led to the conclusion that these molecules can behave very differently from neighboring molecules ensconced in the bulk. A related problem is that, where glassy solid properties are carefully designed to optimize performance, as the material ages its properties can change in undesirable ways. These situations reflect the fact that glassy solids, unlike crystalline solids, are not at equilibrium; and their properties can shift over time.  These changes can affect their performance, and therefore cause problems. This project will produce new ways of modeling glassy solids that will account for the influence of a neighboring surface on how molecules pack. The models will work together with experimental data and lead to new methods for understanding and predicting the ways that glassy material behavior can change when interfaces are present.

Technical abstract

Dynamic relaxation of material begins locally through segmental motion; its progression over short time and length scales drives the longer and larger response. Dynamic behavior also reflects the local structural and energetic characteristics that determine thermodynamic properties. The research proposed here will reveal deep connections between these realms by using and advancing thermodynamic (Locally Correlated Lattice) and dynamic (Cooperative Free Volume) models originated in the PI's research group. This new set of tools will be applied to predict glassy material behavior over a wide range of conditions. Two areas of particular focus involve the presence of interfacial regions and the effect of different experimental pathways used to mimic the effects of long-time aging. This research involves interrelated projects:

(a) A  model will be developed for the interfacial region from very near (nm) the surface to distances where bulk behavior is recovered. It will lead to predictions for local density, mobility (mobile layer thickness), segmental relaxation times, and the changing lengthscale of cooperative motion, as functions of distance from the interface, temperature, and film thickness.

(b) A new model will be introduced for nanocomposites that reflects differences between the interfacial region (next to the particles) and the matrix. This model, informed by thermodynamic properties, will lead to predictions for segmental dynamics and changes in cooperative length scales as functions of temperature, pressure, and nanoparticle loading.

(c) Advances from (a) and (b) will lead to new ways for connecting the thermodynamic and dynamic properties of glass formers to their long term stability.  This work will also lead to insight about how those connections depend on the experimental path to glassiness.

The materials targeted by this project serve an extremely wide range of functions, and this research will lead to new insight about how their molecular nature links to the particular properties that make them uniquely suited to their applications. The new models resulting from this research will be accessible and generally useful for linking thermodynamic properties to dynamic behavior.

The PI will further successful efforts to involve and encourage STEM participation among women and will continue working with graduate and undergraduate students to add new resources on polymer-related science to the public knowledge base. The PI will also continue energetic efforts to introduce fundamental concepts in physical science to the general public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research supported through this award has led to models for understanding and predicting the properties and behavior of solid materials having a glassy (amorphous) structure.  One category of study was glassy thin films, which play key roles in electronics, optics, membranes, coatings, and many other applications. The other was nanocomposites, which are made up of a polymer matrix plus small (i.e. nanometer sized) particles (e.g. silica) dispersed throughout. The particular components can be chosen to meet high performance needs, for example in structural materials that appear in products ranging  from home goods to energy storage to space exploration. A feature shared by all the materials studied is the existence of a large “interfacial” region.  In a nanocomposite this is the area at the surface of the nanoparticles, while in a film it is the region where the material meets air or a solid substrate. Understanding the influence of these regions is key in controlling material properties.

The approach involved simple theoretical and computational models developed in our group. The computational approach is the Limited Mobility (LM) model; it simulates how molten material transitions to a glassy solid. Our LM work led to predictions about  important characteristics and behavior of nanocomposites, successfully capturing effects of different kinds of nanoparticles on the change from melt to glass upon cooling, which happens at the ‘glass transition temperature’, Tg. Turning to analytic modeling, we have created two theories: The Locally Correlated Lattice (LCL) is a fundamental theory  in the area of  thermodynamics; it describes material behavior as pressure, temperature, volume, and composition, are changed.  The Cooperative Free Volume (CFV) theory describes a particular dynamic process such that a molecular segment of a material makes a local hop a distance of about its own size, enabled by some of its neighbors cooperatively moving slightly out of the way. This occurs as part of what is called dynamic ‘relaxation’, whereby a material finds a nondestructive way to dissipate added energy. Since the ability to carry out a segmental hop depends on available space nearby, the presence of an open interface, or of an impenetrable surface (e.g. from a nanoparticle or a substrate) may affect the rate at which this move is successful.

Our nanoparticle studies made use of all approaches described above. The simulation experiments showed that the presence of even completely inert nanoparticles interferes with Tg, and also revealed trends in how changing the particle concentration and the matrix-particle interaction could shift Tg. The simulation results were in strong agreement with  experimental data, and illustrated this fundamental property of a nanocomposite can be ‘tuned’ by choice of polymer, nanoparticle type, and composition. The theoretical studies explained some puzzling experimental data, showing how addition of nanoparticles could indeed lower the density of a composite, yet still not increase the space available for hops, and therefore leave  the segmental dynamics unchanged.

Another series of studies focused on predicting how the presence of interfaces changes local dynamics and the glass transition in glassy materials. A key idea is that knowing the unoccupied, or ‘free’, volume (V-f) in a sample is very revealing. This plus the volume occupied (V-occ) by all of the atoms add together to make up the total volume, V. We showed how V-f can be unambiguously determined from experiment, and revealed links between this quantity and a variety of properties and behavior. For example, our work has led to predictions for changes in segment mobility and sample Tg with film thickness that were subsequently verified by experimentalists. Our studies have also demonstrated that the effects of a free interface are equivalent to the effects of changing the external pressure. Pressure is a very important facet of processing glassy materials into useable objects. So, for example, we can predict how much additional external pressure to apply to an ultrathin film in order to recover dynamics that match a bulk sample at atmospheric pressure. Further, we can make predictions about film behavior using the more readily available data on bulk samples, alone, without needing any experimental data on the films. These studies have demonstrated that using our LCL and CFV models together lead to powerful new insights about materials. 

Alongside these scientific advances, NSF support has enabled us to have a broad impact in the larger scientific and learning communities. The former is related to the applicability of our tools to a range of problems extending well outside our own areas of immediate interest. The latter has been ongoing through the engagement of students at all levels – from undergraduate through post-doctoral – in this work, with an especially strong record of involving women. Further, as the Dean of Science, the PI has been very active in growing and strengthening her academic scientific community.
